U.S. stocks end up; S&P 500 snaps 2-day losing run

This is a Real-time headline. These are breaking news, delivered the minute it happens, delivered ticker-tape style. Visit www.marketwatch.com or the quote page for more information about this breaking news.
Chrysler reports 11% jump in Oct. U.S. auto sales

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Chrysler Group LLC on Friday said it sold 140,083 units in the U.S. in October, a 11% rise from the same month last year and the best October sales since 2007. Chrysler, which is majority owned by Italy's Fiat S.p.A. said six models set sales records in October, including Jeep Wrangler, Jeep Patriot, Dodge Journey, Dodge Dart, Dodge Challenger, and the Ram Cargo Van. The automaker said it finished the month with an 86-day supply of inventory. Broadly, economists polled by MarketWatch expect an average of 15.4 million in total annual auto sales over the past 12 months ending in October, compared with the 15.2 million annual pace seen in September. Shares of Fiat were down 2.6% Friday. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
Final U.S. Markit PMI for October rises to 51.8

WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- The final reading of Markit's U.S. manufacturing purchasing managers index increased to 51.8 in October from an initial "flash" reading of 51.1. It remains below 52.8 in September. The report shows only modest improvement in conditions as any number above 50 signals expansion. Yet the pace of ew orders improved at the slowest pace since April. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
Stocks up at open, try to end 2-day losing streak

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stocks stepped higher at the open on Friday ahead of a key manufacturing report, working to recover from a two-day losing streak. Investors also parsed comments delivered Friday by Federal Reserve officials, looking for their takes on the economic recovery and the central bank's stimulus efforts. The S&P 500 rose 3 points, or 0.2%, to 1,760, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 42 points, or 0.3%, to 15,588. The Nasdaq Composite gained 14 points, or 0.4%, to 3,934. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
Ford Oct. vehicle sales rise 14%, shy of consensus

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Ford Motor Co. reported a 14% rise in U.S. vehicle sales for October to 191,982 units, from 168,456 vehicles a year ago. Retail sales climbed 15% to 142,487, making that the best October since 2004, the car maker said Friday. Sales of passenger cars jumped 19%, while those of utility vehicles rose 9% and truck sales gained 14%. Ford Fusion and Fiesta posted their best-ever October sales, and F-Series topped 60,000 sales for the sixth straight month. The last time Ford sold more than 60,000 trucks for six consecutive months was 2006, it said. Still, vehicle sales fell shy of analysts' expectations of a 15.5% jump to 193,988 units, Overall U.S. car sales are forecast to climb to 15.4 million in October from 15.2 million in September, according to a MarketWatch poll. Ford shares were up 0.4% in early trading. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
Oct. ISM manufacturing index edges up to 56.4%

WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- U.S. manufacturing remained strong in October, according to a closely followed index released Friday. The Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index climbed to 56.4% -- the highest level since April 2011 -- from 56.2% in September. Economists polled by MarketWatch expected a 55% reading, and any reading over 50% indicates expansion. Both the new orders and production indexes have registered above 60% for three consecutive months. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
GM shares rise as Oct. U.S. vehicle sales top view

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - General Motors reported a 15.7% rise in U.S. vehicle sales for October to 226,402 units, from 177,702 vehicles a year ago. The car company said Friday that retail sales climbed 16% while fleet sales rose 14% during the month. The sales tempo picked up after the U.S. government shutdown ended, it added. The figures were stronger than the 10% rise to 215,274 vehicles that analysts had expected. Overall car sales are forecast to climb to 15.4 million in October from 15.2 million in September, according to a MarketWatch poll. GM shares climbed 2.7% in recent trade. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
The Container Store debuts at $36, twice IPO price

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Specialty storage and organization-system retailer the Container Store Inc.'s newly issued shares debuted on the open market riday at $36, double the IPO price of $18 a share. The 62-store chain has posted 13 straight positive comparable-store-sales months and says it has the potential to grow its U.S. footprint to at least 300 locations. Read more: The Container Store doubles IPO price in hot debut. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. China's Qunar soars almost 100% on U.S. debut

SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- American depositary shares of Qunar Cayman Islands Ltd. soared almost 100% on their debut in the Nasdaq Global Market on Friday. The Chinese company priced 11,111,000 shares at $15 per ADS to raise $166.7 million. Qunar is a search-based commercial platform for the Chinese travel industry. Shares of Qunar jumped 99% to $29.82 in recent activity. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
Fed's Lacker: Global market stability a challenge

WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - The effort to build a stronger international regulatory regime in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis is an unfinished top priority for the Federal Reserve, said Jeffrey Lacker, the president of the Richmond Fed, on Friday. "Finding a balanced approach to financial stability will be challenging," Lacker said in a speech to the Global Interdependence Center in Philadelphia. The Fed is working to "level the playing field" across countries and is using several international forums that bring together central banks and national regulators to strengthen to the global financial system, he said. The effort is just the latest of the "international dimensions" that the Fed has had to contend with over its 100-year history, Lacker said. These efforts have always gotten "less attention in popular media coverage than they deserve," he added. The Richmond Fed president did not comment on the U.S. economy or the outlook for Fed monetary policy in his prepared remarks. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
U.S. car and truck sales slip in October

WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Total light vehicle sales fell slightly in October, according to numbers tabulated by Autodata. Sales fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15.23 million, down from 15.28 million in September and below the 15.4 million MarketWatch-compiled economist forecast. That's the lowest rate of sales since April. The biggest decline came from imported cars; domestic cars, domestic trucks and imported trucks all gained. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
Oil futures fall 1.8% on day, down 3.3% on week

SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Oil futures on Friday fell for a fourth straight session to lose more than 3% for the week, pressured by rising U.S. crude supplies as well as a strong advance in the U.S. dollar. December crude fell $1.77, or 1.8%, to settle at $94.61 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Futures prices lost 3.3% for the week, FactSet data, tracking the most-active contracts, show. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
U.S. stocks close higher; Dow up 4th week in row

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stocks advanced on Friday after a solid manufacturing report, closing not far off from their session highs and finishing the week mostly up. The S&P 500 rose 5.10 points, or 0.3%, to end at 1,761.64. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 69.80 points, or nearly 0.5%, to end at 15,615.55. The Nasdaq Composite tacked on 2.34 points, or less than 0.1%, to close at 3,922.04. The S&P 500 and Dow both scored their fourth straight up week in a row, rising 0.1% and 0.3%, respectively. The Nasdaq lost 0.5% for the week, snapping a two-week winning streak. Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move.
